title: Paris-Roubaix will not take place in April
content:
Will Strickson
24 Mar 2021

French newspaper Le Parisien has reported that the Hell of the North will be officially postponed later today

We're going to have to wait a while longer for the return of Paris-Roubaix.

French newspaper Le Parisien reported this morning that the race, originally due to take place on Sunday 11th April, will be officially postponed by organiser ASO later today.

It shouldn't come as too much of a surprise after an emerging third wave of Covid-19 in continental Europe led to the North and Hauts-de-France regions in northern France to be placed into a strict month-long lockdown last Thursday.

ASO had tried to come to an agreement with France's sport and health ministries to have the race go ahead in a bubble and with no spectators, however it was deemed unreasonable at this time to devote public resources including police to a bike race.

Having been postponed and then cancelled in 2020, with the last edition won by Philippe Gilbert on 14th April 2019, it means the wait for the first women's Hell in the North – which was supposed to be held last year – goes on.

Thankfully, Le Parisien is reporting that the race organiser is looking to postpone the race until late October, with the UCI extending the season until 31st October to allow for postponed races to be rescheduled.
